(M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14).proposition: COMPLAINT FOR BREACH OF THE COVENANT OF QUIET ENJOYMENT  (M.G.L. c. 186, § 14)

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 186, § 14, as the acts complained of occurred within the jurisdiction of the Chelsea District Court.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 186, § 14, as the acts complained of occurred within the jurisdiction of the Chelsea District Court.

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease or tenancy-at-will includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, codified in G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly recognizes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in residential leases and tenancies, but it does not state that this covenant is codified in G.L. c. 186, § 14. The case is about constructive eviction arising from breach of the implied covenant and focuses on the landlord’s responsibility for noise from a lounge; it does not discuss § 14 or characterize the covenant as statutory rather than common law. Thus it supports the existence of an implied covenant, but not the specific claim that it is codified in that statute.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). The landlords argue that they did not violate the tenants’ implied covenant of quiet enjoyment because they are not chargeable with the noise from the lounge.

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease or tenancy-at-will includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, codified in G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion clearly recognizes that G.L. c. 186, § 14 creates a statutory quiet enjoyment remedy and applies it to a tenant-at-will, but it does not say that *every* residential lease or tenancy-at-will includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor that such a covenant is ‘codified’ in § 14. The court treats § 14 as a statutory basis for liability when a landlord fails to provide heat, and it refers to breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment generally, but it does not expressly ground an implied contractual covenant in every residential tenancy. Thus it is supportive background authority on quiet enjoyment and § 14, but not direct authority for the specific proposition stated.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’… and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff… It is further established that ‘a tenant may bring an action for civil damages under G. L. c. 186, § 14, without first pursuing [that statute’s provisions for] criminal charges.’… On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14….”}

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: A landlord breaches this covenant when his actions or omissions substantially interfere with a tenant’s beneficial use and enjoyment of the premises.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court explicitly discusses the meaning of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and, relying on prior Massachusetts precedent, explains that liability attaches when the landlord’s conduct has the “natural and probable consequence” of interrupting the tenant’s rights and “impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises.” That is essentially the standard that the covenant is breached by actions or omissions that substantially interfere with the tenant’s beneficial use and enjoyment of the premises. The court then applies that standard to repeated flooding that interfered with Solomon’s use of her apartment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … Although early cases applying the covenant of quiet enjoyment required intent on the part of the landlord … more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.”}

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: A landlord breaches this covenant when his actions or omissions substantially interfere with a tenant’s beneficial use and enjoyment of the premises.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly defines the covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting tenants from serious interference with their tenancy, and emphasizes that a breach can arise from what the landlord did or failed to do, including omissions. It further states that if the landlord’s inaction allows conditions that seriously interfere with tenants’ use of common areas, this may constitute a breach, which matches the proposition that substantial interference with beneficial use and enjoyment violates the covenant.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development… then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … If the defendant failed to take any action… then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Doe v. Springfield Housing Authority*,.proposition: Defendant’s failure to secure the building’s entryway and common areas constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment, as it exposed her to security threats, theft, and fear for personal safety.

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: Defendant’s failure to secure the building’s entryway and common areas constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment, as it exposed her to security threats, theft, and fear for personal safety.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a violation of the lead paint statute, by itself, constitutes a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It does not involve security of building entryways, common areas, or threats to personal safety from third parties. The holding is about the need to show at least negligence and landlord notice to establish a § 14 violation, not about failures to secure premises or resulting security risks, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

*Hemenway v. Alphonse*, 408 Mass. 55 (19.proposition: A landlord’s duty encompasses maintaining common areas in a condition consistent with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment and safety.
*Hemenway v. Alphonse*, 408 Mass. 55 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns standards of proof and due process in emergency child custody (care and protection) proceedings under G.L. c. 119. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, common areas, or any discussion of a landlord’s duty to maintain premises for tenants’ quiet enjoyment or safety. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the stated landlord-duty proposition.

*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.proposition: A landlord’s duty encompasses maintaining common areas in a condition consistent with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment and safety.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly recognizes that landlords owe a duty of reasonable care to maintain premises—including common passageways—so as to ensure the personal safety and quiet enjoyment of tenants and those rightfully on the property. While the case’s main doctrinal shift extends that duty into areas demised to the tenant, the court reaffirms that landlords already had a general and continuing duty to exercise reasonable care as to the safety of common areas under their control, consistent with tenants’ safe use of the property.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.relevant_excerpt: “In the landlord-tenant field, we have held that a landlord is liable to a tenant’s guest for failing to exercise due care in maintaining common passageways under the landlord’s control without regard to their condition at the time of the letting. Lindsey v. Massios, supra. We said that ‘the status of the person visited, landowner or lessee, should not affect the visitor’s right to personal safety or the landowner’s obligation reasonably to maintain premises in his control.’ Id. at 82. In King v. G & M Realty Corp., supra, we extended the landlord’s general and continuing duty to exercise reasonable care as to the safety of common passageways to include tenants as well as their visitors.”

*Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 97.proposition: Defendant deliberately failed to take reasonable steps to restore the security of the premises after receiving notice, thereby “directly or indirectly interfering” with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 97.support_reasoning: The opinion does involve violations of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and serious security defects (a flimsy door leading to an assault), but the quoted portion focuses on c. 93A damages, trebling, and the landlord’s bad‑faith refusal to repair after a demand letter. It does not analyze or articulate the specific statutory standard that a deliberate failure to take reasonable steps to restore security after notice constitutes “direct or indirect interference” with quiet enjoyment under § 14. Any support for that proposition would be inferential, not a stated legal rule or holding.
*Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 97.relevant_excerpt: “These damages were based on a September, 1980, incident in which LeClair was assaulted with a knife by a neighbor after the neighbor punched a hole through LeClair’s hollow core front door and entered his apartment. The judge found that the construction of the door to LeClair’s apartment did not provide adequate security and was in violation of the State Sanitary Code… The question whether the requisite causal connection has been shown is one of fact… We are unable to say that the findings of the judge on this issue were clearly erroneous.”

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was not only negligent but willful, given Plaintiff’s multiple reports and the foreseeable harm caused by continued inaction.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses negligence, intentional infliction of emotional distress, and willful or knowing violations under Chapter 93A, but it does not use or define “willful” in the sense of willful (or reckless) misconduct as a heightened form of negligence. The court upholds findings that Haddad’s conduct was “intentional and outrageous” and supports multiple damages for willful/knowing Chapter 93A violations, not that his inaction in response to complaints transformed negligence into willful misconduct. Thus, it does not affirm the specific proposition that defendant’s conduct was “not only negligent but willful” based on multiple reports and foreseeable harm from continued inaction.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.relevant_excerpt: “On the emotional distress counterclaim, the judge determined that Gonzalez had proved that Haddad's intentional and outrageous conduct had caused her to suffer severe emotional distress, and that such proof constituted a basis for recovery under c. 93A. … The judge expressly found that Haddad knew, or should have known, that severe emotional distress was the likely consequence of his conduct; that Haddad's conduct was beyond all bounds of human decency; that Haddad's conduct caused Gonzalez emotional distress; and that Gonzalez's emotional distress was extreme and severe.”

*Goreham v. Martins*, 485 Mass. 54 (2020.proposition: As a result of Defendant’s breach, Plaintiff sustained actual damages, including stolen property and required expenditures for personal security, entitling her to compensation and statutory remedies pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, including minimum statutory damages, reasonable attorney’s fees, costs, and any other relief deemed just and proper.

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: As a result of Defendant’s breach, Plaintiff sustained actual damages, including stolen property and required expenditures for personal security, entitling her to compensation and statutory remedies pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, including minimum statutory damages, reasonable attorney’s fees, costs, and any other relief deemed just and proper.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The case concerns breach of the implied warranty of habitability and the tenant’s right to rent abatement when the landlord fails to provide adequate heat and hot water, irrespective of fault. It does not involve stolen property, expenditures for personal security, or any discussion of G.L. c. 186, § 14, statutory minimum damages, attorney’s fees, or related statutory remedies. Therefore it does not support the specific proposition about compensable actual damages of the type claimed or entitlement to remedies under c. 186, § 14.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: "The trial judge found that the measure of damages was ‘the difference between the value of the apartment as warranted and the rental value of the apartment in its defective condition.’ ... Apart from the question whether the tenant’s rent abates only after the landlord has had a reasonable time to repair, damages are not in dispute in this case."
